August 5, 1955.

Mr. Lewis Anderson,
Box 151, Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

Dear Mr. Anderson:

We have received the questionnaires which you recently returned to the Archives, Nos. 1 and 3 to 10. Thank you very much for your interest and cooperation in completing all the questionnaires which we have issued, and thus making available this information for research purposes. All questionnaires returned to us by early settlers are permanently preserved in the Archives.

Unfortunately the Archives has no funds for purchasing or reimbursing people for records or information which they supply to us. None of the other early settlers who have completed questionnaires for us have received any payment, and I am afraid we are unable to make any exception in your case. I quite realize that it required a good deal of time and effort to send in as complete an account as you have done, and we very much appreciate receiving the material. It will be of satisfaction to you to know the information of the area in which you pioneered will be available in future years to those who are interested.

Yours sincerely,

Evelyn Eager
Assistant Archivist

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

(Instructions: Please answer as many of these questions as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask. where it will be preserved as part of the permanent record of our Province.)

Name: A.W.S.A.N.O.E.A.S.O.N.
Address: Box 151, N.A.C.A.M., SASK.
Birthplace: Quill Lake, N.W.T.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? I was born in 1902.
Where did you set up housekeeping? Near Quill Lake.
Where had you been living before that? Between Quill Lake & Yorkton.
For how many people did you prepare meals? Six and at times more.
How far was it to your nearest store? 120 miles.
How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a year.
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, salt, pepper, coffee, tea, baking powder, soda, cereals.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS

What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Lake of the Woods Five Roses.
In what quantities did you buy it? 10 bags at a time.
What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? $2.30.
How much did you use graham flour? Just in making brown bread.
Whole wheat flour? Making whole wheat bread.
Was flour milled locally? At times. How far away? 25 miles. What year? Around 1908.
What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 40¢.
What other grain products did you use? Rolled oats.
Cornmeal? Whole Wheat? Yes. Farina?
Other?
Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? In later years.
How did you grind it? With a commercial mill.

PIONEER DIET: WHAT DID WESTERN CANADIAN PIONEERS EAT?

This questionnaire is designed to elicit information about the diet of Western Canadian pioneers. It will provide valuable data for historians and genealogists.

4. DAIRY PRODUCTS

How did you get a supply of fresh milk in the early days? By milking the cow.

Butter? churn.

Eggs? hen laid them.

What was the price of butter? 10¢ per lb.

Did you pack eggs for winter? Yes.

Did you make butter? Yes.

What kind of cheese? Primrose, cottage, gamalost.

5. MEAT AND FISH

What was your meat supply in the early years? Beef & Pork.

How did you get fresh meat? Whenever butchered.

How often did you get fresh meat? Spring and fall.

How did you preserve meat? In winter kept frozen, salt brine during summer.

Was there a "beef ring" in your neighborhood? No.

If so what year was it organized?

Did you use game? Yes.

What kinds? Ducks, Geese, Prairie chickens, Rabbits.

For how long? During season.

What part did fish play in the family diet? Not extensive.

Was the fish fresh, cured, or canned? Fresh, canned, cured.

Kinds? Jack fish, Perch, White fish, Salmon, finn Haddock.

16. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible). At first it seems to me wooden boxes chiefly were used, tea usually came in tin boxes, green coffee beans in wooden kegs. Salted herring came in wooden kegs, tin foil was extensively used.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest year you can remember. Give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

For breakfast we used to have eggs, oatmeal porridge, toast, butter and coffee. For dinner meat, potatoes (boiled & mashed), bread, butter and milk desert. For supper fried potatoes, meat, bread, butter, desert and tea. This would be about 1908 my brother being about 2 yrs old.

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today. There were no pressure cookers in the early days otherwise cooking was much the same as today.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible). To this day I personally prefer the home grown foods and do not rely on commercially prepared unless living in an isolated place such as a lighthouse.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandizing, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed). In the early days Watson was our market town approximately 25 miles away. From about 1906 J.W. Hutchison operated an inland store and post office. During winter months we marketed our grain and during the fall months we would lay in a year's supply of bulk supplies such as flour sugar and coffee. Flour was usually purchased in 20-25 lb lots sugar 5-800 bags salt 2-50 lb bags Coffee 100 lbs. This stuff was stored in the attic of the house.
